name: Maryam Abdel-Azim
school: Central Bucks High School East, Doylestown, PA
project_title: Targeting Signaling Molecules of P. aeruginosa by Using Mucin as an Anti-Quorum Sensing Drug: A Novel Design To Evaluate Efficacy in the Context of Multidrug Resistance
description: Maryam Abdel-Azim, 17, of Doylestown, investigated ways to disrupt quorum sensing (QS), one method cells use to communicate, in the harmful bacteria Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Her research showed that by manipulating compounds found in mucus, QS can be decreased or prevented, opening the door to developing drug alternatives to antibiotics.

name: Saraswathy Amjith
school: Tesla STEM High School, Redmond, WA
project_title: A Novel Integrated Machine Learning Approach Utilizing Radar and Satellite Imagery for Selective Logging Remote Sensing Detection and Accompanying AI-Logging Map-Generating Webtool
description: Saraswathy Amjith, 18, of Redmond, developed a way to more accurately identify illegal logging. She found that she could help compensate for cloudy weather by combining satellite optical and radar datasets, since radar imagery is not affected by clouds.

name: Aarav Arora
school: Del Norte High School, San Diego, CA
project_title: A Mechanistic Basis for the Analysis of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron Variant Severity
description: Aarav Arora, 18, of San Diego, developed a different approach to use patient symptom data and a mechanistic basis to analyze the severity of the Omicron variant of COVID-19. He used statistical methods to identify which mutated variants cause the most severe symptoms.

name: Aditi Avinash
school: Rock Canyon High School, Highlands Ranch, CO
project_title: Model Validation and Preclinical Testing of Digestive Enzymes for Gluten Breakdown: A Move To Cure Gluten Intolerance and Celiac Disease
description: Aditi Avinash, 17, of Castle Pines, found a mixture of three enzymes that she believes could one day be used to reduce the effects of gluten intolerance. Her work indicated that combining the enzymes was more effective in breaking down gluten and reducing the immune response of T-cells.

name: Harshil Avlani
school: BASIS Chandler, Chandler, AZ
project_title: Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits
description: Harshil Avlani, 17, of Chandler, researched a way to describe quantum computing errors by observing physical qubits as they are exposed to the quantum mid-circuit measurement (MCM) gate at various distances. His results suggested that the MCM gate causes a significant increase in 'spectator qubit' errors.

name: Arav Bhargava
school: The Potomac School, McLean, VA
project_title: Low-Cost, 3D-Printed, Universal-Fit, Transradial Socket for Amputees in Developing Countries
description: Arav Bhargava, 18, of McLean, created a low-cost universal socket, a segment of a prosthetic arm. His 3D-printed socket with circumference and length-expansion mechanisms can be made for less than $40 and can be adjusted to fit a wide range of residual limbs.

name: Alan Bu
school: Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH
project_title: On the Maximum Number of Spanning Trees in a Planar Graph With a Fixed Number of Edges: A Linear-Algebraic Connection
description: Alan Bu, 17, of Glenmont, made connections between graph theory and linear algebra. His project provides precise limits on the number of spanning trees a planar graph can have, making these estimates much more precise through connections to linear algebra.

name: David Lu Cao
school: Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Alexandria, VA
project_title: The Implications of 'Oumuamua on Panspermia
description: David Lu Cao, 18, of Vienna, investigated the origin of life on Earth. Inspired by the 2017 discovery of 'Oumuamua, he analyzed the possibility that microorganisms might have arrived here from elsewhere in the universe billions of years ago by hitching a ride inside comets or asteroids.

name: Arnav N. Chakravarthy
school: Homestead High School, Cupertino, CA
project_title: Leveraging Mitochondrial DNA Mutations for Macrophage Lineage Tracing in Primary Human Tissues
description: Arnav N. Chakravarthy, 18, of Sunnyvale, investigated how macrophage cells replenish in aging humans. His findings show promise for the regenerative possibilities of macrophage cells, including those that affect age-related diseases like Alzheimer's.

name: Sophie Chen
school: Caddo Parish Magnet High School, Shreveport, LA
project_title: Intraoperative Histological Analysis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma Tumor Margins Using a Convolutional Neural Network
description: Sophie Chen, 17, of Shreveport, developed a convolutional neural network machine learning model to review microscopic images of tissue during removal of squamous cell carcinoma. Her model proved to be robust, fast, and able to accurately identify suspicious tissues from images.

name: Thomas Cong
school: Ossining High School, Ossining, NY
project_title: Overlooked Covariates in Metabolite Abundance Levels: Systematically Quantifying the Information Overlap Between Gene Expression and Metabolism Across Multiple Cancer Types
description: Thomas Yu-Tong Cong, 17, of Ossining, researched the rapid growth of certain types of cancers. He concluded that factors like the cancer's tissue of origin, its surrounding environment in the body, and how many cancer cells there are in a mass, strongly influence metabolic signatures.

name: Sophie D'Halleweyn
school: Bronx High School of Science, Bronx, NY
project_title: Alleviating the Energy Crisis: A Novel Multi-Task Machine Learning Algorithm for Designing Efficient Nanocatalysts To Reduce Industrial Energy Impact
description: Sophie D'Halleweyn, 17, of New York, developed a machine-learning algorithm to optimize the design and production of catalysts. She demonstrated the effectiveness of the approach by applying it to palladium-based nanoparticles, used in batteries, fuel cells, and microchip production.

name: Sophie Gao
school: Hunter College High School, New York, NY
project_title: Uncovering Mechanisms of Action and Resistance for KRAS G12D Inhibitor MRTX1133 Using Drosophila melanogaster Models
description: Sophie Gao, 17, of New York, studied a protein blocker's ability to combat a tumor-causing cell protein that exists in some of the deadliest cancers. She found that higher dosages of the protein blocker MRTX1133 led to higher survival in fruit fly models.

name: William Gao
school: Centennial High School, Ellicott City, MD
project_title: Designing a Federated Learning-Driven Collaborative Diagnostic System for Metastatic Breast Cancer: Reducing Long Diagnosis Delays and Improving Patient Survival Outcomes in Developing Countries
description: William Gao, 18, of Ellicott City, created a diagnostic image analysis tool that reduces delays in the diagnosis of metastatic breast cancer. His system includes safeguards for patient privacy and can be deployed using a smartphone.

name: Sarang Goel
school: Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science, Denton, TX
project_title: IVY â€“ Intelligent Vision System for the Visually Impaired: Innovative Low-Cost, AI-Based Eyeglasses To Help the Visually Impaired Overcome Mobility Limitations Through Navigational Assistance and Object Avoidance Algorithms and an Intuitive Vibration and Audio Guidance System
description: Sarang Goel, 18, of Irving, developed a vision technology for people with failing eyesight to increase their mobility. His Intelligent Vision System (IVY) consists of eyeglasses device, automated mapping and navigation algorithms, and costs less than $300 to make.

name: Jacob Tyler Gross
school: Roslyn High School, Roslyn Heights, NY
project_title: Investigating Synergistic Interactions Among SARS-CoV-2 Neutralizing Antibodies
description: Jacob Tyler Gross, 17, of Roslyn, investigated whether synergistic interactions may increase the power of current antibody treatments for COVID-19 infection. He found that an antibody called S309 works better in combatting an Omicron subvariant when combined with another antibody class.

name: Luke Huang
school: New Canaan High School, New Canaan, CT
project_title: Binary Cellular Analysis: Understanding the Link Between Aging and Mortality Risk
description: Luke Huang, 17, of New Canaan, developed a mathematical model that assesses how cellular damage increasingly elevates the risk of death as people age. He believes this insight could validate the basis for studying anti-aging treatments.

name: Vincent Weisi Huang
school: Syosset High School, Syosset, NY
project_title: A Smart Computer Program LauePt4 for Recognizing and Simulating Laue Patterns and Its Applications
description: Vincent Huang, 17, of Syosset, developed a computer program to address a longstanding obstacle in crystallography: how to easily determine a crystal's internal atomic structure. He wrote a program that simulates a crystal's Laue pattern and interior lattice orientation.

name: Howard Ji
school: University High School, Irvine, CA
project_title: Development of a Novel Autonomous Column-Climbing Robotic System (AutoBot) for Real-Time Detection and Mapping of Surface Cracks on Bridges
description: Howard Ji, 17, of Irvine, created a robot to make inspections of aging bridges safer. His AutoBot uses wire wrapping to hold itself onto bridge columns and software he created to map surface damage in real time.

name: Amanrai Singh Kahlon
school: Sanford School, Hockessin, DE
project_title: Enhancing Wearable Gait-Monitoring Systems: Identifying Optimal Kinematic Inputs in Typical Adolescents
description: Amanrai Singh Kahlon, 17, of Hockessin, utilized specialized sensors that measure motion to investigate how to enhance assistive walking technology with machine learning. He identified two signals based on sensor placement that produced consistent, robust data.

name: Gavriela Beatrice Kalish-Schur
school: Julia R. Masterman High School, Philadelphia, PA
project_title: IRE1 Knockdown Leads to an Anxiety Phenotype in Drosophila and Changes in BiP and BDNF Levels
description: Gavriela Beatrice Kalish-Schur, 18, of Philadelphia, studied a potential neurological cause of anxiety using fruit flies as a model. She manipulated the fruit flies' genetics so that the IRE1 pathway was decreased in different parts of the brain.

name: Zeyneb N. Kaya
school: Saratoga High School, Saratoga, CA
project_title: MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation
description: Zeyneb N. Kaya, 17, of Saratoga, improved resources for machine learning models to help preserve endangered languages. She wrote an algorithm called MADLIBS that generates additional text to help NLP algorithms work better with low-resource languages.

name: Natasha Kulviwat
school: Jericho High School, Jericho, NY
project_title: The Neurobiology of Suicide: Blood-Brain Barrier Breakdown as a Novel Suicide-Risk Biomarker
description: Natasha Kulviwat, 17, of Jericho, searched for a biomarker to identify people at risk for suicide. Her research suggests that high levels of albumin and the protein claudin-5 may serve as early markers of suicide risk.

name: Alexis Li
school: Hamilton High School, Chandler, AZ
project_title: BrainSTEAM: A Practical Pipeline for Connectome-Based fMRI Analysis Toward Brain Disorder Classification
description: Alexis Li, 17, of Gilbert, developed a suite of machine learning tools that identify key neural patterns in neuropsychiatric conditions. Her BrainSTEAM tool analyzes blood flow information in functional MRI images to determine brain connection strengths.

name: Alexandra Mahajan
school: Cambridge Rindge & Latin School, Cambridge, MA
project_title: A Novel Method To Determine Precise Stellar Radii and Temperatures of Low Mass Stars Using JWST Transits and Occultations
description: Alexandra Mahajan, 17, of Cambridge, developed a new method to measure the radius and temperature of small stars. She analyzed data from the James Webb Space Telescope to achieve more accurate measurements of low-mass stars.

name: Ekansh Mittal
school: Westview High School, Portland, OR
project_title: Harnessing Machine Learning and 3D Spheroid Cultures To Identify Biomarkers for Combating Drug Resistance in Breast Cancer
description: Ekansh Mittal, 17, of Beaverton, investigated genes responsible for drug resistance in breast cancer treatments. He identified over 30 genes that predicted drug resistance and found that inhibiting IGF1R significantly increased the death of cancer cells.

name: Ramon Moreno Jr.
school: Thousand Oaks High School, Thousand Oaks, CA
project_title: The Influence of Isonicotinamide on the Chronological Lifespan of Saccharomyces cerevisiae Strains
description: Ramon Moreno, 17, of Thousand Oaks, studied the potential of the chemical compound isonicotinamide (INAM) to extend the lifespan of yeast cells. He found significant correlations between INAM's influence and cell growth in different yeast strains.

name: Ella Pilacek
school: Oviedo High School, Oviedo, FL
project_title: Promoting Attraction of Apis mellifera to the Synthetic Scent of the Endangered Orchid Prosthechea cochleate Using Pavlovian Conditioning and Direct Feeding Paradigms for Conservation
description: Ella Pilacek, 17, of Winter Springs, researched Pavlovian conditioning of honeybees to promote pollination of endangered native orchids. She successfully trained non-native honeybees to be attracted to synthetic orchid scents.

name: Achyuta Rajaram
school: Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH
project_title: Automatic Discovery of Visual Circuits
description: Achyuta Rajaram, 17, of Exeter, improved automatic discovery of visual circuits in machine learning. He developed an automatic method for recognizing which parts of computer vision algorithms identify what in images.

name: Rhea Rastogi
school: Loveless Academic Magnet Program High School, Montgomery, AL
project_title: Understanding How the Maternal Epigenetic Reprogramming Function of LSD1 Contributes to Inherited Developmental Disease
description: Rhea Rastogi, 18, of Montgomery, explored whether errors in histone methylation affected future generations. She found that offspring of worms missing certain enzymes had developmental delays and decreased fertility that accumulated in later generations.

name: Kun-Hyung Roh
school: Bronx High School of Science, Bronx, NY
project_title: Novel Drug Discovery Methodology Using Machine Learning for Gene Expression-Based Virtual Screening Predicts Novel Compounds To Reverse Alzheimer's Disease With Applications to Cancer and Longevity by Inhibiting CtBP2 Expression
description: Kun-Hyung Roh, 18, of New York, created A.I. software to ease potential drug discovery by identifying compounds that inhibit gene expression of proteins. He focused on Alzheimer's disease and developed a machine-learning method to identify new potential drug candidates.

name: Linus Tang
school: Davidson Academy Online, Reno, NV
project_title: Extremal Bounds on Peripherality Measures
description: Linus Tang, 17, of San Jose, researched peripherality measures in graph theory. He proved tighter upper and lower bounds on the values that can be achieved by several numerical measures of peripherality and refuted two previous conjectures.

name: Riya Tyagi
school: Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH
project_title: Using Computer Vision To Disentangle Features Enabling AI To Learn Self-Reported Race and Ethnicity From Medical Images
description: Riya Tyagi, 16, of Exeter, sought to understand how convolutional neural networks determine patients' self-reported race and ethnicity. She discovered a potential cause of bias in the U-Net segmentation model widely used for medical image processing.

name: Grant Wang
school: Williamsville East High School, East Amherst, NY
project_title: MLOffense: Multilingual Offensive Language Detection and Target Identification on Social Media Using Graph Attention Transformer
description: Grant Wang, 17, of East Amherst, created an A.I. model to detect offensive content posted on social media in 100 languages. His model examines the context of entire sentences to gain a nuanced understanding of the writer's intent.

name: Michelle Wei
school: The Harker School, San Jose, CA
project_title: Solving Second-Order Cone Programs Deterministically in Matrix Multiplication Time
description: Michelle Wei, 17, of Saratoga, improved second-order cone programming solvers. She showed that SOCP problems may always be converted into a modified form that has the same answer but is faster to solve.

name: Nathan Wei
school: Buchholz High School, Gainesville, FL
project_title: Novel Elastomeric Polystyrene via Photopolymerization and Post-Functionalization of Durable Ultra-High Molecular Weight Perfluorostyrene Copolymers
description: Nathan Wei, 17, of Gainesville, synthesized an ultra-high molecular weight plastic. He demonstrated that a UHMW polymer could be created under blue light with much lower energy requirements and produced a recyclable version with strong material properties.

name: Julianne Wu
school: University High School, Irvine, CA
project_title: Sex-Related Signaling of the Angiotensin II Pathway in Primary Aortic Smooth Muscle Cells
description: Julianne Wu, 17, of Irvine, explored the effects of testosterone and estrogen on arterial tissue. She noticed that when male arterial cells were exposed to estrogen, the presence of a protective receptor called angiotensin II type 2 increased.

name: Selina Zhang
school: North Hunterdon High School, Annandale, NJ
project_title: ArTreeficial: A Novel AI-Integrated Solution to Reducing Invasive Spotted Lanternfly Populations
description: Selina Zhang, 18, of Annandale, designed and field tested a synthetic, eco-conscious, A.I.-powered tree that uses machine learning to selectively lure and 'zap' the invasive spotted lanternfly. Her solar-powered prototype costs under $200 to construct.

name: Christopher Zorn
school: Irvington High School, Irvington, NY
project_title: The Role of MYC in RET Fusion Tumorigenesis and RET Inhibitor Resistance
description: Christopher Zorn, 17, of Irvington, studied how RET and MYC genes affect one another in genetically modified lung cancer cells. He found the MYC levels were elevated in most cell lines and often led to treatment resistance.

name: Charisse Zou
school: Dougherty Valley High School, San Ramon, CA
project_title: The Development of a Free-Flying Method To Study the Effect of Neonicotinoids on the Positive Transfer of Learning in the Visual Domain of Honeybees
description: Charisse Zou, 17, of San Ramon, investigated how two commonly used insecticides affected the cognitive abilities of honeybees. She discovered that exposure to imidacloprid reduced medium-term memory while clothianidin damaged long-term memory.
